metadata.sermon_title: The Line between Good and Evil
metadata.sermon_start_end: It is significant that you included a prayer for our enemies in the intercessions this morning. In my travels around the country I have noticed that very few churches are praying for our enemies [...] The promise of God to sinners today is that it will be reckoned to us who believe in him that raised from the dead Jesus our Lord. AMEN.
metadata.notes: Delivered at Lenape Valley Presbyterian Church in 2006, heavily influenced by the post-9/11 political climate.

logos.analysis: The sermon exhibits a strong, traceable rational architecture that moves from the cultural-political context to theological anthropology and finally to soteriology. The preacher utilizes a 'thematic-inductive' approach, beginning with the observation of public rhetoric (Good vs. Evil) and systematically dismantling it using historical examples (Lincoln, Havel) and biblical exegesis (Romans). The logic is consistent: if the line between good and evil runs through every person, then self-righteousness is a delusion, and universal need for justification is the only logical conclusion. The transition from the 'problem' of sin as a power to the 'solution' of justification is handled with dogmatic precision.
quotes: The line between good and evil did not run clearly between ‘them’ and ‘us,’ but through each person.
I find it to be a law that when I want to do right, evil lies close at hand.
Justification means that we sinners will not only be forgiven, we will be justified, which means that we will be set right by the power of God.
strengths: Clear thematic thread regarding the 'internal line' of morality.
Effective use of historical and literary parallels (Lincoln, Shakespeare, Havel) to support the biblical argument.
Traceable transition from the human predicament (Romans 7) to the divine solution (Romans 4).
improvement_points: The connection between the Lincoln historical section and the specific exegesis of Romans 3 could be more tightly integrated.
The conclusion introduces the concept of 'power' somewhat abruptly compared to the earlier focus on 'guilt' and 'justification'.
Some illustrations (the McWain company) feel slightly detached from the primary logical flow of the Romans text.
logos.specific_diagnosis: Strong internal consistency that successfully bridges secular history and Pauline theology.

pathos.analysis: Pathos is achieved through vivid, often unsettling imagery and 'slices of life' that evoke recognition and shame. The description of the screaming girls in Montgomery and the story of the alcoholic 'man of his word' are designed to puncture the hearer's emotional defenses. However, the tone remains somewhat restrained and intellectual. While it touches on 'existential questions,' it does so with a diagnostic distance rather than a warm, affective appeal. The emotional resonance is more about 'sober realization' than 'heart-stirring joy,' which fits the pre-Advent/repentance theme but may feel 'cold' to some listeners.
pathos.emotional_tone: Sober, diagnostic, and confrontational regarding human denial.
quotes: The faces of the girls are contorted. They are screaming something. They look as though they are consumed with anger and hate.
The wife was dying inside because the husband would not accept his part of the struggle.
Great was their disillusionment when it became clear that he was not going to stop, could not stop, and in fact, in the end, drank himself to death.
strengths: Use of sensory details (the photograph, the screaming) to create identification.
Effective appeal to the shared human experience of 'denial' and 'struggle'.
Avoidance of cheap sentimentality in favor of 'weighty' emotional honesty.
improvement_points: The transition to the 'Good News' at the end lacks the same descriptive emotional depth as the descriptions of sin.
The language is occasionally more academic than affective (e.g., 'psychological phenomenon famously called denial').
Could benefit from more direct address to the hearer's specific hopes or fears beyond the collective 'we'.
pathos.specific_diagnosis: Effective use of 'shock' and 'recognition' pathos, though slightly clinical in delivery.

ethos.analysis: The Ethos of the preacher is the strongest element. The speaker establishes credibility not through personal boasting, but through a 'witness' stance that includes themselves in the critique. By stating 'Forty years ago one of them might have been me,' the preacher moves from a position of moral superiority to one of shared solidarity. The authority is derived from a deep immersion in both the biblical text and the 'text' of human history. There is a palpable sense of integrity and a refusal to pander to the political or religious 'self-confidence' of the audience.
ethos.authenticity: High; the preacher speaks as one who is also 'under the power of sin' and subject to the message.
quotes: In my travels around the country I have noticed that very few churches are praying for our enemies... It is not good for our Christian health to fail him in this regard.
Forty years ago one of them might have been me, or you, captured in sin by the camera for life.
So this morning we are placing the emphasis on the predicament that you and I share, every single one of us here today.
strengths: Strong 'witness' role: the preacher stands under the judgment of the text alongside the congregation.
Intellectual humility combined with spiritual conviction.
Courageous addressing of contemporary political idols (post-9/11 rhetoric) without being partisan.
improvement_points: The use of 'I have a file' could occasionally come across as a bit 'expert-centered' rather than purely pastoral.
More personal vulnerability regarding the 'struggle' mentioned in Romans 7 could further humanize the Ethos.
The southern identity remarks are interesting but could be perceived as a distraction from the universal Ethos of the messenger.
ethos.specific_diagnosis: Exceptional credibility established through solidarity in sin and submission to the Word.

rhetorical_balance_analysis.analysis: The sermon is remarkably well-balanced, though it leans heavily on the credibility (Ethos) and logical structure (Logos) of the argument. The preacher uses Ethos to earn the right to speak hard truths about sin, and Logos to ensure those truths are anchored in Scripture rather than just opinion. Pathos is used strategically—not to manipulate, but to ground the abstract theology in 'dirty' reality. The balance serves a 'prophetic-diagnostic' purpose: it seeks to convince the mind and convict the conscience.
consequences_of_imbalance: The intellectual weight (Logos/Ethos) might leave more 'feeling-oriented' hearers feeling analyzed rather than comforted.
The heavy focus on 'solidarity in sin' could lead to a sense of hopelessness if the final 'power' section is not delivered with sufficient affective energy.
The sermon reaches the 'thinking' believer effectively but may struggle to move the 'will' of those who need a more direct emotional appeal.
rhetorical_balance_analysis.recommendation_for_balance: Increase the 'Pathos' of the concluding section. The description of Christ's 'invasion' and 'disarming' of the rebel could be made as vivid and sensory as the description of the screaming girls in Montgomery.

orthodoxy_logos.analysis: The sermon is highly orthodox, maintaining a strict Pauline view of total depravity and justification by grace. It avoids moralism.

orthopathy_pathos.analysis: Awakens a 'godly fear' and 'sober humility,' though perhaps lacks the 'joy' typically associated with the arrival of the Gospel.

orthopraxy_ethos.analysis: The preacher models the 'lowly spirit' and 'repentance' called for in the text, speaking as a fellow-traveler in the 'fraternity of Adam'.

overall_picture.summary: This is a high-quality, intellectually rigorous sermon that effectively challenges the 'good vs. evil' dualism of its era. It succeeds by shifting the rhetorical focus from 'the evil others' to the 'internal line' within the self. The preacher's use of historical figures like Lincoln provides a secular bridge to a deeply theological point, making the doctrine of total depravity accessible and relevant. While the sermon is rhetorically 'heavy' and leans toward the diagnostic, it maintains a clear thread and concludes with a robust, if somewhat brief, proclamation of the Gospel. It is a model of how to use Ethos to deliver a difficult message of judgment and grace.
strengths_top_3: Courageous and credible Ethos that avoids self-righteousness.
Sophisticated integration of history, literature, and exegesis (Logos).
Powerful, concrete illustrations that force self-examination (Pathos).
improvement_points_top_3: The transition to the 'power' and 'victory' of Christ feels rushed compared to the analysis of sin.
Some academic phrasing could be simplified for broader affective impact.
The conclusion needs more 'heart-pathos' to match the 'head-logos' of the justification argument.
overall_picture.audience_analysis: Most appealing to educated, reflective hearers who are skeptical of simplistic political/religious rhetoric.
recommendations_for_next_sermon: Spend more time developing the 'affective' side of the Gospel's beauty.
Try to use fewer 'file' references and more 'lived' pastoral observations.
Ensure the 'Good News' has as much descriptive 'weight' as the 'Bad News'.
overall_picture.conclusion: A strong, sober, and intellectually coherent sermon. It excels in Ethos and Logos, providing a necessary corrective to the cultural self-righteousness of its time. While it could benefit from a more emotionally resonant conclusion, it stands as an excellent example of 'witness-based' preaching that refuses to exempt the speaker from the text's judgment.
